awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: The Origin and Evolution of Nectaries in Non-Flowering Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Fellow's name: Jacob S. Suissa

Proposal number: 2208845

Research title: The origin and evolution of nectaries in non-flowering plants

Sponsoring scientist(s) and host institution(s): Dr. Fay-Wei, Lee Boyce Thompson Institute and Dr. Corrie Moreau, Cornell University

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Interactions between plants and animals are ecologically important, and plants have traits that evolved to affect these interactions. Understanding how and why these traits have evolved remain some of the most important biological questions. The fellow aims to take a step closer to answering these questions by exploring the early evolution of plant nectar glands. Nectar glands (nectaries), are common in flowers, but also occur in certain non-flowering plants, like the ancient fern lineage. In ferns these nectaries attract ants that feed on the nectar and fight off insects that want to eat the plant. Yet, we do not know when these nectaries evolved in ferns or whether the underlying genes responsible for their development are similar to those in flowers. The fellow’s work is important in that it will reveal the early evolution of nectaries, potentially shifting our understanding of the evolution of these structures and early plant-animal interactions. 

Broadly, the fellow aims to explore the origins and evolution of nectaries in a three-part multidisciplinary research program. First, integrating data on the timing of nectary evolution in ferns and flowering plants with major radiations of insect lineages, he will determine when, why, and how nectaries first evolved. Then, by using RNA-sequencing across divergent fern species he will uncover the genes underlying nectary development in ferns. He will then use comparative transcriptomics to determine if genes expressed in fern nectaries are similar to those of nectaries in flowering plants. Finally, using comparative genomics across land plants, he will pinpoint when this genetic toolkit first evolved. The fellow hypothesizes that nectaries evolved first in ferns before flowering plants, and that nectary genes in ferns are likely stomatal or phloem-specific genes which evolved early in the evolution of land plants. In addition to his research, the fellow is also committed to outreach and science communication. He plans to continue his work of democratizing the study of plant biology through his social media platform Let’s Botanize.  He is also dedicated to creating a more equitable and inclusive field of science by mentoring undergraduate students from historically marginalized groups during the Cornell University Summer Research Internship program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to uncover the origin and evolution of sugar-secreting nectar glands, known as nectaries, in non-flowering plants. This research has yielded significant scientific contributions that advance our understanding of plant biology, symbiosis, and evolution.


First, we developed a comprehensive dataset documenting the presence of nectaries in 150 fern species and 3,913 flowering plant species. In addition, we aggregated the largest datasets available on ant-plant interactions and fern herbivores. This provides a resource for future research into plant-animal interactions and the evolution of these unique structures.

Second, we successfully assembled a high-quality genome for the bracken fern, a species with notable nectar-secreting abilities. We also generated extensive gene expression data from fern nectaries at various stages of development, providing insights into the genetic components underlying nectary formation and function.


Third, we produced the first untargeted metabolomics dataset detailing the chemical composition of fern nectar. This dataset opens new avenues for exploring how nectar composition influences ecological interactions, such as those between ferns and their herbivores or pollinators.

The first part of this research was published in Nature Communications (doi: 10.1038/s41467-024-48646-x), where it garnered significant attention, including popular science articles in Science News Explorers and coverage on The Common Descent Podcast.

This work has broader implications for both science and society. Scientifically, it enhances our understanding of plant-animal co-evolution and the genetic basis of nectary evolution, which could inform future crop breeding programs aimed at enhancing natural plant defense systems.

In terms of educational impact, this project provided hands-on research training for two undergraduate students. Additionally, a workshop on fern evolution was conducted as part of the Cornell Plant Biology course. To further broaden the impact, we produced a major science communication video on extra-floral nectaries in both flowering plants and ferns. This video has reached over 68,500 views on social media, demonstrating substantial public interest. 

Throughout the project, we collaborated on science communication videos with four colleagues, emphasizing partnerships with underrepresented students in STEM. These efforts aimed to highlight and elevate the voices of Black scientists at Cornell. Our outreach extended to various public engagement events, including the Boyce Thompson Institute’s Breaking Ground science communication seminar, Insectapolooza Day, and presentations to elementary school children at the Ithaca Science Center as part of their Science Connection series. Furthermore, we authored a SciComm Conversation article to convey our research findings to the general public and presented this work at the 2023 Botany and Evolution Conferences.
